title: How do vinyl records warp? - Quora

response.answer_text: When vinyl heats up, it becomes soft. Pressure on the vinyl, including the album’s own weight, can cause it to warp. It is very important to store your records properly so that they don’t warp. Keep them away from heat, and also be sure to avoid leaving them in direct sunlight. I do not advise playing records with more than a slight warp on a good turntable, or a turntable that you plan to play good records on in the future without replacing the stylus. This is because playing a warped record puts excessive pressure on the cantilever (the cantilever connects the needle to the cartridge). If this becomes damaged, your records will too. If your needle is jumping off of the vinyl, then it is probably time to look for another copy of that album. However, if you’d still like to play a very warped album, I have found that 60’s/70’s BSR turntables and the like do a nice job playing warped records. I’m guessing that this is because of the heavy tracking force that they use.

Traditional product PVC has a maximum operating temperature around 140°F (60°C) when heat distortion begins to occur. Melting temperatures range from 212°F to 500°F (100°C to 260°C) depending upon manufacture additives to the PVC. Vinyl is “V” in PVC and its the same thing. So, when vinyl records get too hot, they start to loose their shape. They warp.
